nodes.bodyText: I think we need to clean these up when the channel closes. Maybe slightly tricky, we might close the channel concurrently with calling this method too.
Good catch. I pushed cbe02c7.
Can we assert it was removed?
++. Adjusted in 09a612e.

I wasn't expecting this to be included here, although perhaps it makes sense as a separate change. It's reasonable if the node is shut down but today we also cancel these tasks if the node is temporarily partitioned from the master, and perhaps we want to keep that behaviour.
The issue is that we don't tell the partitioned node that it has been dropped from the cluster so it won't close its outgoing channels, which means we won't cancel those tasks any more if we remove this.
Also looks like the tests around this are quite weak, since this change doesn't seem to have a corresponding change to the tests.

This has become an issue for us in the context of cross clusters. A subtask on the remote cluster will get canceled if any node in that cluster leaves. The reason is that the node with the parent task is from another cluster. This blocks the work to support cancellation cross clusters in #55779. We would like to replace it with the task heartbeat, but I found your proposal is much better.

Also looks like the tests around this are quite weak, since this change doesn't seem to have a corresponding change to the tests.

Yeah, we only test when a node leaves the cluster.
I see, in which case this change is ok with me. Could we make that test stronger? It seems very artificial that the tasks are only cancelled on testNodes[0].close();.

The issue is that we don't tell the partitioned node that it has been dropped from the cluster so it won't close its outgoing channels, which means we won't cancel those tasks any more if we remove this.

That looks like an enhancement to me. If the channel is still active we should give a chance for the task to finish ?
ok, I pushed 8ae7042.
Maybe log a warning here?
added in d4f7586

What if the channel is closed (and the close listener executes completely) just before this line executes? I think that means we never cancel the task added in this line.
Could we have a test with some concurrency to pick this up?
Good catch. I added a test and strengthen this logic in bdfa4f2.
Do we need to add multiple listeners ? I think  it would be cleaner to move the logic to cancel a task directly in the TaskManager and call it from TransportCancelTasksAction ?
We need a single listener - I switched to SetOnce in 1d2de32. I exposed this method so we can cancel child tasks.

I think we should move this code (cancelTaskAndDescendants) in the TaskManager and expose a simple TaskManager#cancel method that this action can call. That would remove the need to have public methods in  the TaskManager around bans and orphaned tasks. They should be private and solely used by the TaskManager to cancel a task internally ?
Thanks for pushing this 👍 . I've moved the cancellation to TaskManager in bd29504.
Looks like there is a race condition that leads to an AssertionError. See my comment below, I think the logic to cancel a task and its children/descendants should be entirely in the TaskManager.
Should be fixed in bd29504
why isn't it instantiated when we create the TaskManager (TransportService#createTaskManager) ?

I tried to avoid exposing TransportService when it's not fully initialized yet. Also, there are several circular dependencies between TransportService, RequestHandlerRegistry, TaskCancellationService, and TaskManager. I will look into how to pass TaskCancellationService to the constructor of TaskManager.
